Headline: Creating India‚Äôs First Finance Voice & Opportunity Network | Turning Public Opinion into Real Impact
Comment:
Agreed Rishabh. But at the same time i believe both are equally important.

In today's market if you aren't seen being a new brand. At very first go specially in consumable category consumer tries a product out after repeated visibility. They slowly trust over time and then they try out hoping it would be good. If they are not even seen, the first purchase will be extremely difficult, and repeat won't even come into picture. Ofcourse, Consistent product quality is a mandatory offering. 

So new brands should use advertising to some extent in lean and optimised way to build awareness which will lead to first round of purchase and product quality will then help them to retain and get repeat orders. 

Over the time if marketing spend is not going down and repeat isn't going up, then i believe that's an issue of PMF which is a bad indicator.

Headline: Investing | Private equity | Healthcare | Climate resilience
Comment:
Could not agree more. The big learning I still treasure from my early career years at P&G was that brands are built by focusing on repurchase rates, NOT only awareness. While people think that P&G (and Unilever) focus mainly on creating great brand communication (they do that also), you could argue that they are actually great marketers because they have great products that consumers love and recommend ... not only because the products are 'advertised extensively'. 

As we now look for investment opportunities in global consumer businesses at the Penumbra Fund, repurchase rate and having a core loyal group of consumers are the single most important criteria to assess the strength of the brand! Not advertising noise levels!
